property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: null

property.name: text
property.value: GOES-CIMIS point data regression. Given a date and an hour, this workflow gets temperature point data from two sources: the CIMIS stations and a GOES infrared channel. The GOES infrared data is converted to temperature (I2T actor). Only locations where data is available from the two sources are considered for the regression analysis. This intersection is done by the Inters actor.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward A. Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: Use the Annotation attribute to annotate a workflow. Double-click the attribute to customize the content, font size, color, and basic formatting (bold and italics).

property.name: prop:fontFamily
property.configure: The font face. Select a font from the drop-down menu. The default is "SansSerif".

property.name: prop:italic
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be italics. By default, type will not be italicized.

property.name: prop:bold
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be bold. By default, type will not be bold.

property.name: prop:textColor
property.configure: The font color. Specify a string representing an array of four elements: red, green, blue, and alpha, where alpha is transparency. The default is an opaque black, {0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0}

property.name: prop:textSize
property.configure: The font size. Select an integer from the drop-down menu or specify a new size by typing it directly into the value field. The default is 14.

property.name: prop:text
property.configure: The text of the annotation.

property.name: expression
property.value:
sgnf <- function(v, ...) signif(v, 3, ...)
if (is.character(Dependent)) { Dependent <- factor(Dependent) }
model <- lm(Dependent ~ Independent)
R2 <- summary(model)$r.squared
plot(Independent, Dependent, xlab="GOES", ylab="CIMIS", asp=1)
if (is.numeric(Dependent)) { abline(model) intercept <- as.numeric(model$coefficient[1]) slope <- as.numeric(model$coefficient[2]) title(main=paste("R^2 =", sgnf(R2)), sub=paste("b =", sgnf(intercept), " m =", sgnf(slope))) intercept slope
# Save the data for external usage: csvname <- "goescimisdata.csv" csv <- file(csvname, "w") cat(paste("# R2=", sgnf(R2), sep=""), paste("# m=", sgnf(slope), sep=""), paste("# b=", sgnf(intercept), sep=""), file=csv, sep="\n") close(csv) write(paste(Independent, Dependent), csvname, append=TRUE) } if (is.character(Dependent)) { ano <- anova(model) ano }
#eps <- function(file, onefile=FALSE, horizontal=FALSE, paper="special", ...) # postscript(file=file, onefile=onefile, horizontal=horizontal, paper=paper, ...) # #eps(file="plot.eps", width=5, height=5) #dev.off()

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Josh Madin

property.name: version
property.configure: null

configure.p: The Regression actor uses R to run a variance or linear regression analysis. The actor accepts an independent and a dependent variable. If the independent variable is categorical, the actor uses R to run a variance analysis (or a t-test if the variable has only 2 categories). If the independent variable is continuous, a linear regression is run. The actor outputs both a graphical and textual representation of the analysis.

The R application must be installed on the local system to use this actor. R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. For more information about R, see http://www.r-project.org/.

The actor performs the analysis and saves the results to the Kepler working directory. To view the results, connect an ImageJ actor to the graphicsFileName output port and/or a Display actor to the intercept and slope ports.

property.name: port:slope
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the slope of the generated result.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a copy of the text output that R generates. As the actor communicates with R to run the R function or script, the output port sends back the response (i.e., the values and statistical outputs).

property.name: port:graphicsFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the generated graph of the results.

property.name: port:Dependent
property.configure: The dependent variable (continuous).

property.name: port:Independent
property.configure: The independent variable (continuous or categorical).

property.name: port:intercept
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the y-intercept of the generated result.

property.name: prop:Rcwd
property.configure: The 'R' working directory (the home directory by default).

property.name: prop:displayGraphicsOutput
property.configure: Select to display the plot once the actor has generated it.

property.name: prop:graphicsFormat
property.configure: The graphics output format. Currently the actor supports either *.pdf or *.png.

property.name: prop:numXPixels
property.configure: The width of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:numYPixels
property.configure: The height of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: The expression that is evaluated to produce the output.

property.name: prop:save_nosave
property.configure: Specify whether or not to save the R workspace when R is closed; set to '--save' to retrieve the workspace later in a workflow in another R-actor.

property.name: prop:graphicsOutput
property.configure: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: description
property.value:
The Regression actor uses R to run a variance or linear regression analysis. The actor accepts an independent and a dependent variable. If the independent variable is categorical, the actor uses R to run a variance analysis (or a t-test if the variable has only 2 categories). If the independent variable is continuous, a linear regression is run. The actor outputs both a graphical and textual representation of the analysis.

The R application must be installed on the local system to use this actor. R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. For more information about R, see http://www.r-project.org/.

The actor performs the analysis and saves the results to the Kepler working directory. To view the results, connect an ImageJ actor to the graphicsFileName output port and/or a Display actor to the intercept and slope ports.

property.name: expression (parameter)
property.value: The expression that is evaluated to produce the output.

property.name: Rcwd (parameter)
property.value: The 'R' working directory (the home directory by default).

property.name: save_nosave (parameter)
property.value: Specify whether or not to save the R workspace when R is closed; set to '--save' to retrieve the workspace later in a workflow in another R-actor.

property.name: graphicsFormat (parameter)
property.value: The graphics output format. Currently the actor supports either *.pdf or *.png.

property.name: graphicsOutput (parameter)
property.value: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: displayGraphicsOutput (parameter)
property.value: Select to display the plot once the actor has generated it.

property.name: numXPixels (parameter)
property.value: The width of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: numYPixels (parameter)
property.value: The height of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: graphicsFileName (port)
property.value: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the generated graph of the results.

property.name: output (port)
property.value: An output port that broadcasts a copy of the text output that R generates. As the actor communicates with R to run the R function or script, the output port sends back the response (i.e., the values and statistical outputs).

property.name: slope (port)
property.value: An output port that broadcasts the slope of the generated result.

property.name: intercept (port)
property.value: An output port that broadcasts the y-intercept of the generated result.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Dan higgins

property.name: version
property.configure: null

configure.p: The ImageJ actor reads an image file name and opens and displays the image along with a toolbar of image-processing options, which can be used to process the image.

The actor uses the ImageJ application to open and work with images. ImageJ can be used to display and process a wide variety of images (tiffs, gifs, jpegs, etc.) For more information about ImageJ, see http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: A multiport that accepts the path of an image file (a tiff, gif, jpeg, or any other format supported by ImageJ). The file name can also be input through the fileOrURL parameter.

property.name: prop:fileOrURL
property.configure: The file name or URL of an image to process (a tiff, gif, jpeg, or any other format supported by ImageJ). The file name may also be input through the input port.
